quotes.text: I think the hard part is sublimating your ego a little bit and saying it's more important to get to the outcome than to be right.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Practical advice for handling disagreements by prioritizing outcomes over personal correctness.

quotes.text: I love this very tactical piece of advice when you're trying to come up with a metaphor or analogy, think about what you want your users to feel when you're using the product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete method for crafting product metaphors by anchoring on the target user emotion.

quotes.text: For me, the hill climb is all about the difference between a local optimum and a global optimum.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for strategy and persistence when short-term progress conflicts with long-term goals.

quotes.text: Most of us are winging it and learning as we're going and learning through trial and error and it's all normal. It's all fine and I can do it and you can do it, and everyone.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A counter-narrative that normalizes uncertainty and iterative learning behind “successful” careers.

quotes.text: I for a long time felt like I was held back because I don't have a plan, but I realized that probably the most important thing is to just acknowledge that that is true for me.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A reframing that turns the absence of a rigid plan into self-awareness that can guide better career decisions.

quotes.text: The best way to level up your career is to surround yourself with extraordinary peers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear, actionable career-growth lever: intentionally curate a high-caliber peer group.

quotes.text: When you have a trusted group of peers, you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice and just gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Defines the practical functions of a peer group as an ongoing decision-quality and perspective-checking mechanism.

quotes.text: 93% of members say Sidebar helped them achieve a significant positive change in their career.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete outcome metric that quantifies the claimed impact of structured peer leadership groups.

quotes.text: Why spend a decade finding your people when you can meet them at Sidebar today?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: accelerate relationship-building via a program instead of relying on slow, organic networking.

quotes.text: Getting to market fast is a top priority for product teams, and the last thing that you or your developers want is to build document workflows from scratch.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Practical product strategy advice: avoid rebuilding commodity infrastructure that slows time-to-market and distracts from core differentiation.

quotes.text: And I have that engine in my head also, but what I try to do is work through the spreadsheets and then tear it up because none of that stuff is actually going to determine how good I am at the job.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Ami challenges overly rational career planning by arguing that spreadsheet logic doesn’t predict on-the-job performance.

quotes.text: The thing that'll determine... In my track record, the thing that has determined it is when I walk through the doors, do I feel like I'm lucky to be there?
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: She offers a simple emotional litmus test for role selection that correlates with doing great work.

quotes.text: I try to just put on the coat of the job.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for simulating a role to evaluate fit beyond titles and trajectories.

quotes.text: When I wake up in the morning, I'm like, what would it be like if I were doing this job? What would I think about on my commute? Who would I have lunch with? Do I like them? What problems am I going to solve today?
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A practical set of questions practitioners can use to “try on” a job and gauge day-to-day motivation and team fit.

quotes.text: And for me, the thing that has led me to the places where I do my best work is a feeling of being at home, which is all about trust and trust with the people around me.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: She identifies trust as the core predictor of high performance and sustained risk-taking in a new role.

quotes.text: Other people have a bunch of information that I do not have. And so I'm just ignoring that, I was letting my ego overtake my desire to get to the best outcome, which is just, that's a silly trade off and an unnecessary one.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Ami reframes disagreement as a signal of missing context and highlights ego as the main obstacle to better decisions.

quotes.text: But it's made work and life so much more interesting to just be like, hey, what does this person know that I don't know yet? It means that every meeting you walk into, you're probably not going to get bored and I get bored a lot, but if you assume that every person there knows something that you don't know, then it's not just wait to get to the right answer, it's like, discover the thing that they know that you don't know and it becomes just a little bit of uncovering.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A practical mental model: enter every conversation assuming others have unique information, turning conflict into discovery.

quotes.text: I just try to think about the feedback loop of, I think all of life is feedback loops, so I just started to think about the feedback loop I'm creating of like, I was curious about something. I learned something new, we got for a better outcome. Probably the other person felt better as well as I felt better. It's all positive feedback and you do that a couple of times and the positive feedback far outweighs the desire to be right because now we're more right, we're more right together.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: She offers a repeatable mechanism—build a positive feedback loop where curiosity compounds into better outcomes and relationships.

quotes.text: For me the most important thing is just taking a pause. I think when you just take a pause, your body calms down, your mind gets a chance to breathe a little bit, and then your response is going to be better, but you got to take the pause because the immediate visceral reaction, is not always... It's going to be primal, it's going to be protective. It's just when you take a pause you're like, this is all fine, let's just learn.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Concrete tactic for high-stakes disagreement: pause to interrupt the primal/protective reaction and reopen learning.

quotes.topic_title: Dinosaur brain: how to run product reviews
quotes.text: Assume that executives have a little tiny dinosaur brain. We all have a little brontosaurus brain and we can really only hold three facts at the same time. We will never be able to go deep in the way that you are able to do on everything that crosses our desk. And so the best service you can do is actually do the work of making a recommendation.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why teams should synthesize and recommend rather than overload execs with raw information.

quotes.topic_title: Dinosaur brain: how to run product reviews
quotes.text: I think we misuse product reviews sometimes as ways to get decisions and actually, they should be ways to calibrate on principles.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Reframes product reviews from one-off decision meetings into principle-setting forums that scale decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Dinosaur brain: how to run product reviews
quotes.text: So what you don't want is to come to a product review for every single that you want to make. Instead, what you want is to come to a product review with one decision, but the goal of that decision is to walk out with principles about how to make these decisions in the future so that you don't have to come to product review, but you still have this consistent and coherent product that you're building.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A concrete operating approach: use a single decision as a vehicle to extract reusable principles and reduce future review load.

quotes.topic_title: Dinosaur brain: how to run product reviews
quotes.text: I think the temptation is always to err toward writing more, and what I always really recommend people do is write whatever you need to write and then cut out almost all of it.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for making reviews sharper by forcing clarity and reducing noise.

quotes.topic_title: Dinosaur brain: how to run product reviews
quotes.text: I mean I do think that usually fewer people is better. It leads to a sense of being informal and that is really useful because it lowers the bar on how complete or strong these conversations are and I'd rather have a less formal conversation faster than a formal conversation and lose three weeks in the process when we could have been building.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A counterintuitive meeting-design principle: smaller, more informal reviews can speed execution and reduce process drag.

quotes.topic_title: Metaphors to align teams: hill climb
quotes.text: For me, the hill climb is all about the difference between the local optimum and a global optimum.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for explaining why teams must sometimes stop optimizing the current system to pursue a bigger opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Metaphors to align teams: hill climb
quotes.text: But then way off from the distance you can see a mountain, one that's even higher than you can't even see the top of it, and you have to decide, are you going to take the risk of climbing down your hill, crossing an unknown chasm, and then climbing back up, just to get to the same level you started at with more climbing to do to get to that summit?
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A vivid way to set expectations that reaching a higher “global optimum” requires temporary regression and uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Metaphors to align teams: hill climb
quotes.text: Most of the time the answer is yes, but it's helpful for me to know, boy, this feels like a slog. It is supposed to? Because I'm still in the valley and the thing that gets me through the valley is remembering what the summit feels like.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Practical guidance for normalizing the “valley” period so teams don’t misinterpret temporary pain as failure.

quotes.topic_title: Metaphors to align teams: hill climb
quotes.text: Narrative can carry so much weight and water where otherwise it's similar to the product review point, where either you can tell everybody exactly what to do at every point or you can create a story that we all agree on.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A scalable leadership methodology: align teams through shared narrative instead of detailed instructions.

quotes.topic_title: Metaphors to align teams: hill climb
quotes.text: But you don't have to go and make all those individual decisions. You can buy into the same story and then people will just naturally build something that feels more consistent.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Actionable insight on how metaphors reduce coordination overhead and improve consistency across functions (design, comms, product).

quotes.text: And the most universal form of communication is face-to-face. When you talk to someone face-to-face, you're not thinking, how do I present? What tool do I have to learn? You just open your mouth and words come out, and that's the feeling that we wanted to create.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Ami shares a practical way to anchor product decisions in a universal user feeling, using a clear metaphor as the north star.

quotes.text: And it's all really a small thing. It's like a typing indicator is like someone who's about to take a breath, give them a second to talk, the two check marks lighting up or someone's face lighting up when they hear you, it's just a recognition of being heard.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: She gives concrete examples of how tiny UI details can cumulatively create a powerful emotional experience.

quotes.text: I get very bored a lot. It's another way to make sure meetings are really interesting where you're like, okay, let me see what that person is going to say next. Let me put myself in their shoes. Let me think about what they're reacting to and why they're going to think that and how they're going to see the world.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Ami describes a repeatable practice—mentally emulating others—to expand perspective and improve real-time collaboration.

quotes.text: And again, it just gives me more toolkits because it means when I'm stumped on something, I can be like, what would Rob Goldman say? He'd say, look at the dashboard. Have I looked at the dashboard? No. Okay, let me go look at the dashboard.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: She offers an actionable “leader emulator” method: borrow specific leaders’ default moves to unblock decisions.

quotes.text: I really, one the metaphors was sitting around in your family room when you think about how to make calls work, where when you're sitting in a family room, you're not scheduling it, you're not, I don't know, having this cold corporate feeling, the way you do with a conference where there's heavyweight interactions, and instead there's just, you can join and leave. It feels lightweight, it feels like the space exists even when you're not there.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Ami shows how a vivid metaphor can directly translate into product requirements (e.g., joinable calls) and align a team on what to build.

quotes.text: I really, one the metaphors was sitting around in your family room when you think about how to make calls work, where when you're sitting in a family room, you're not scheduling it, you're not, I don't know, having this cold corporate feeling, the way you do with a conference where there's heavyweight interactions, and instead there's just, you can join and leave.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Ami shares a concrete product metaphor teams can use to design communication features around an emotional goal (casual presence) rather than meeting-like formality.

quotes.text: It feels lightweight, it feels like the space exists even when you're not there.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A crisp articulation of the desired user feeling that can guide UX decisions for real-time communication products.

quotes.text: And so just creating things like joinable calls, like that feeling of people popping in and just paying attention to whoever's there and letting them leave, but the call can flow on without a super heavyweight action that everyone needs to take.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A specific example of translating a narrative (“family room”) into an actionable feature principle (drop-in, low-friction participation).

quotes.text: I think that was another one where we were just able to agree on the feeling and then you know what to build.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A practical method: align the team on the target feeling first, then let that drive concrete product decisions.

quotes.text: Customers don't care about your fancy strategies and your five-year plan. They care about the product that's in their hands.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A crisp reminder to prioritize shipping and user impact over long-range planning artifacts.

quotes.text: And so anything that distracts you from thinking about the product in your hands I think, or maybe worse, takes you away from solving customer's problems today, I think is a distraction.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A practical filter for deciding what work to deprioritize: if it pulls you from today’s customer problems, it’s likely waste.

quotes.text: And what's even worse is that you have learned nothing. You don't know whether it was your strategy that was wrong or whether it was your execution that was wrong, all you know is you didn't win.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A learning-focused argument for execution: poor execution destroys your ability to diagnose what failed.

quotes.text: Whereas when you have a pretty good strategy, a good enough strategy, you're in the right direction and you have perfect execution, you still don't win immediately, but you know your execution was great. So then you learn, what do you need to do to improve your strategy? You've got the execution machine, you go back, you update your strategy, you relaunch, and you keep on doing it until your strategy is perfect and then you do win.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A repeatable iteration loop: execute well to isolate variables, then refine strategy based on real market feedback.

quotes.text: It is the nuts and bolts and sometimes boring, sometimes grind it out work of like, you got to bring the donuts, you got to look at the dashboards, you got to rewrite the spec. You got to just do a bunch of the grinding, but that is what leads to the customer's outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Concrete examples of what “execution” actually looks like day-to-day—and why it’s the real driver of outcomes.

quotes.text: Get fast feedback throughout the development process so that you can build the right thing the first time, make better decisions that lead to better business outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable product-development guidance: use continuous user feedback to reduce iteration cycles and improve decision quality.

quotes.text: Companies are being asked to do more with less.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concise framing of the operating environment that motivates prioritization, speed, and efficiency in product work.

quotes.text: They need to move quickly to build experiences that meet changing customer expectations and do so faster than ever, all while minimizing risk and costly rework.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical set of constraints (speed + shifting needs + risk reduction) that can guide process and tooling choices.

quotes.text: They empower user research, product and design teams to make higher confidence decisions with human insights.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A decision-making model: increase confidence by grounding choices in direct human/user insight across functions.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing strategy vs execution by seniority
quotes.text: So you should spend some time, maybe it's like 20% of your time, but the bulk of your time should be confirming that strategy actually makes sense for the customers.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Gives a concrete time-allocation heuristic that prioritizes customer validation over extended strategy work.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing strategy vs execution by seniority
quotes.text: Getting it out there, building the machine to constantly make it better, as opposed to a perfect strategy.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Emphasizes an execution system and continuous improvement loop over trying to craft an idealized strategy upfront.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing strategy vs execution by seniority
quotes.text: I don't 100% know that that's true.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that seniority necessarily means spending less time on execution and more on strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing strategy vs execution by seniority
quotes.text: I think that's, I mean, how much time can you spend thinking about the future, as opposed to actually trying to create it.
quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that pushes leaders to bias toward action that shapes outcomes rather than abstract planning.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing strategy vs execution by seniority
quotes.text: For strategy to be useful, it actually has to change our behavior as a team to create better customer outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Defines a practical test for whether strategy is real: it must alter team behavior in ways that improve customer results.
